clean_story:
"Sky addresses. Numbers that pinpoint stars. "

The term celestial coordinate systems comes from "celestial" (meaning "of the sky") and "coordinates" (numbers that mark a location).

Imagine the night sky as a giant, invisible globe wrapped around Earth.

Instead of streets, we use angles—like a cosmic GPS—to name where stars, planets, or galaxies sit.

Two main systems exist:
Altitude-Azimuth (like a compass for the sky) measures up/down and left/right from your spot on Earth.
Right Ascension-Declination (the sky’s latitude/longitude) fixes positions as if Earth’s equator stretched into space.

Example: The star Vega sits at RA: 18h 36m 56s, Dec: +38° 47′—its unchanging "address" in the RA-Dec system.

Telescopes use these numbers to auto-lock onto objects, even as Earth spins.

Without them, "point at that bright dot" would be the only instruction.

Three related subjects are star catalogs history, Earth’s axial precession, and pulsar timing arrays.
